dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luminous Pacific Island scene — palm trees, hula girls a crescent of golden sand that borders vibrant ocean, illustrated 1950s style. PULLING BACK to reveal a Pacific tapa cloth pattern borde a kitsch lamp-shade. Black Sambuca swirls into a shot glass on a shiny black b JAKE SAWYER, late 20s, handsome and haunted-looking, knoc the shot back and slams the glass down. IN A DARK CORNER OF THE BAR, Jake picks up a payphone receiver. His fingers hover over the buttons, reluctant t dial ... he hangs up. Jake picks up a leather bag from beside his bar stool. As reaches down, we see a long, pale scar on his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. SINGAPORE STREETS/SEDAN
dialogues.text: Rain hammers down as a dark Mercedes sedan rolls through Singapore’s streets. INSIDE, Jake watches the lights blur past the rain-streak glass. A CHAUFFEUR drives silently. OUTSIDE, the bustle gives way to a more stately part of t the affluent Holland District.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls up outside an old property. The house reeks of both old money and new. Expansive grounds fall a into darkness beyond the haze of rain. Jake steps out of the car. Thunder rolls overhead as he l up at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chauffeur shows Jake into a marbled foyer. A staircas sweeps up into darkness. Jake shivers. A figure descends the stairs. MR LIM is silver haired and slight. He looks like he hasn’t slept in weeks. He extend hand.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Edward Lim.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Jake Sawyer. Jake shakes Mr Lim’s hand. As he does, we see that the ba of Jake’s hand is covered with intricate tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-appointed living room, mahogany and leather, pools shadow. Jake sits in an armchair, flipping through a worn looking leather journal. Mr Lim paces, wringing his hands

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Have you ever encountered a bad spirit, Mr Sawyer?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Almost every night.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: It is eating him from within. So strong ... so hungry. Unseen by Mr Lim, Jake rolls his eyes. He hands Mr Lim th journal. We can’t see what’s on the page.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is what you need.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: (impressed) How did you get this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (grins) Ed, you worry about your karma, let me worry about mine.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: It’s powerful?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (laying it on thick) And strictly forbidden. I’m taking a big risk giving this to him. Mr Lim hands Jake an envelope. Jake looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: It is enough? Jake's eyes glint in triumph: it’s more than enough.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Lim leads Jake up a long, shadowy hallway. Jake approa the door as if this creepy setting is all in a day’s work Lim opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake steps into the room. Candles flicker, incense burns. walls and ceiling are scrawled with Chinese symbols. A YOUNG BOY (13) sits up on the bed. He looks flu-ridden miserable. Breath rattles as his scrawny chest rises and falls. Seeing the child, Jake looks taken aback — clearly this wasn’t what he expected. From behind him, the sound of rapid, CRUNCHING FOOTSTEPS. Jake turns —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps crunch through snow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slender teenager runs towards a dark house: YOUNG JAKE. Behind him, a dark treeline. Out of breath, he looks back afraid —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake blinks. Mr Lim watches him from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You never said he was a kid. He looks back at the sick boy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you seen a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: This isn’t something a doctor can cure ... but you can. Can’t you? Jake wrestles with this, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If that’s the way you want to go.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: We must be prepared to do anything for our loved ones. Even if it causes them pain. (to the boy) This is the man I told you about. He’s here to help us. Jake sits down beside the boy, clearly uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, kid. I’m Jake. What’s your name? The boy watches him, wide-eyed, fearful. JAKE (CONT’D) (smiles) Strong and silent type, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Is this going to hurt? Another flicker of guilt crosses Jake’s face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Your Dad thinks it’s going to help you get better.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: What do you think? Jake meets the boy’s eyes, then looks away, unable to lie Jake opens his bag. A TATTOOIST’S NEEDLE is deftly assemb He skims through the notebook: images of hand-drawn symbo flutter past. Jake’s needle BUZZES. The tattoo takes shape under its po an ancient Thai symbol, lines etched with skill and precision. Jake wipes blood and ink from the child’s skin. He glance to see that the boy is sobbing quietly. His father holds boy's wrists tightly, his knuckles white. He whispers desperate assurances to the boy in Malay. Behind the boy’s sobs, a ROAR builds —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shivering with fear, Young Jake huddles against a cracked grimy mirror in a dark basement corner. Beside him an iro boiler roars and rattles ... TIC-TIC-TIC-TIC ... A DARK FIGURE looms, its reflection fragmented in the mir A BLADE flashes, slices SKIN, BLOOD wells — Young Jake SCREAMS —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scream seems to reverberate around the tight hallway Jake steps out of the bedroom, bag in hand. He looks back Beyond, Mr Lim kneels at his son’s bedside in prayer. Jak turns away and strides up the hall, his expression grim.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey ... EXT. SINGAPORE TATTOO EXPO/JAKE’S BOOTH - DAY 12 The sprawling bustle of a convention, a multi-cultural microcosm of booths, stages, showcases and tents. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A banner reads TATTOO EXPO 2007 in both English and Chine Music booms. Jake hesitates, needle hovering over a partially complete tattoo around a skinny forearm. The design is striking, tribal motifs in black ink.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Huh? His wiry Singaporean CUSTOMER looks up at him, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: I said, is this for real? Jake slips effortlessly back into salesman mode:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You ever hear of a Dayak tribesman with carpal tunnel syndrome? Jake continues tattooing. Behind them, a sign above Jake’s stall reads MYSTICAL TAT FOR PROTECTION AND WELL-BEING. Posters show ethnic design and their promised effect: GOUT, RHEUMATISM, HEMORRHOIDS more. Ethnic tattooing tools decorate the walls, an attempt to the display some credibility.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Big night last night, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Nothing I can’t handle.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Jake stuffs his tools into his bag. He shoulders it, look to see a figure watching him: MR LIM. If he looked sleep- deprived the night before, he now looks positively zombif

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Your tattoo did not work.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) It was just a tattoo. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Then the fault is yours. Evasive, Jake looks around to see who might be listening.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Listen, you believe in I Ching, Feng Shui or faery folk, that’s your business ... but next time your kid gets sick, you really want him to get better, take him to a doctor! Jake pushes past Lim and disappears into the crowd. Mr Li stares after Jake, trembling with rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake glances back over his shoulder as he pushes through crowd. Mr Lim is still following him. Jake slips between booths — Ahead is a large tent. TAP-TAP-TAP! The sound emanates fr darkness. TAP-TAP-TAP! Jake ducks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake stands in the shadows of the tent entrance, watching crowd pass by. No sign of Mr Lim. Behind him, the TAP-TAP continues. A young woman, SINA, watches Jake from the shadows of the tent. She’s in her early 20s, beautiful, a red hibiscus flower behind her ear. Her eyes travel to the scar on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Can I help you? Jake turns to see her. In awe and off-guard, he struggles find his voice:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sina! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sina disappears into the darkness of the tent, towards th source of the sound. Jake watches after her ... then foll The main area of the tent is bathed in the soft glow of candlelight. Soft Pacific dub plays from an old boom-box. Jake steps forward, captivated ... SEMO (early 20s) lies half-naked amid the other men. An incredible tattoo in progress spreads across his buttocks down his legs: THE PE’A, a traditional Samoan tatau. The tattooist leans over him. ALIPATI’s lean body is coiled l a spring, shining with sweat. Sina sits down beside Semo and begins to massage his temp She whispers in his ear, soothing. Dark ink is poured, thick like blood. A bone tool is dipp Skin is stretched taut. One of the onlookers, PENI, holds Semo’s skin taut for Alipati — TAP-TAP-TAP! Another tool falls and black ink spatters, t is wiped away to reveal the vivid lines of tatau beneath. general sense of calm, of serene concentration. Jake's eyes pick up other details: a single tear runs dow Semo’s cheek. The ragged hitch of his breathing. Alipati leans to whisper in Semo’s ear:

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Time out, brutha. Semo moves to sit up, leans on Alipati for support. Their heads touch and they share each other’s breath, bef Semo nods and manages to sit up. Jake watches this exchan of trust, astonished — he’s never seen a tattooing experi shared so powerfully. Sina watches as Jake takes this all in, enjoying the impression the display is making.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (impressed) Jesus. Alipati looks up, notices Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: You looking for him, you got the wrong tent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alipati gets to his feet. His full pe’a wraps around his thighs and torso, dazzling in its intricacy, the spaces between the ink luminous in the golden light. ALIPATI (CONT’D) Flash tats, bro — got something to prove? Jake nods towards Alipati’s tatau.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: You get the pe’a, you don’t gotta prove nothing to anyone, ever again.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is from the South Pacific, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Samoan tatau, outta Auckland.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: New Zealand? Jake looks around. A DISPLAY of ancient tattooing TOOLS, and wood bound with flax, is carefully arranged on a tapa cloth draped over a desk to one side. They look as though they haven’t been used for many years. Jake picks up a bone tool from the display at peers at it The points are needle-sharp. JAKE (CONT’D) Do they have any medicinal value? You know, protection, healing, that kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: (scoffs) You mean like ‘Tattoos for Protection and Wellbeing’? Jake grins, good-natured but nevertheless defensive.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, a man’s got to make a living. Alipati approaches Jake, his gaze intense. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: This ain’t just a living. You get the pe’a to honour the spirits of your tupuaga, who wore it before you. You get it to honour your father. And your father’s father.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What if your father isn’t worth honouring? Alipati narrows his eyes, nods, as if Jake has just given away some crucial detail. Sina watches, interested. Jake takes a step back as Alipati leans in close, his voi soft, emphatic:

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: The pain of the tatau, it changes you. You breathe into it, accept it, learn from it. Only then can you find a way through. Alipati’s hand snaps out and grabs Jake’s wrist, turns it over to reveal the livid scar on Jake’s inner arm. Alipat nods, as though the scar confirms his suspicions about Ja ALIPATI (CONT’D) You know what I’m talking about. You seen pain. Only, you ain’t found a way through yours, eh? These words strike Jake, seem to sink in ... then defensiveness kicks in. He tries to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m just looking for some styles to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: That ain’t all you’re looking for. (beat) Sometimes it’s right in front of your eyes, brutha. You just gotta open them. Jake yanks his arm from Alipati’s grip, eyes blazing with anger. Alipati smirks and turns away, as if unsurprised b Jake's reaction. Jake turns to leave, fuming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ALIPATI (CONT’D) (his back to Jake) It was a rose. With a barb wire stem. Jake freezes for a moment, eyes wide ... then steps out o the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the tent, Jake looks down — he still holds the bo and wood tool he was looking at before. With a last glance back towards the tent, he stuffs it in his pocket and strides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake is back in his spot at the bar, a shot of Sambuca in front of him. Behind him, the post-convention crowd is a of leather, ink and pierced flesh under black-light and n Jake seems disconnected from the world, his expression distant as he toys absently with the tool he stole. Despi the crowd, he is alone. A heavily-tattooed middle-aged man leans over.

dialogues.speaker: TATTOOED PUNTER
dialogues.text: Lemme guess — tattoo me with that and my dick’1l grow four inches overnight?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You never know. Jake turns away ... to see Mr Lim pushing through the bar towards him. He looks for an exit, but he’s cornered. JAKE (CONT’D) Look, what do you want — a refund?

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: If you don’t believe, your actions have no power. They can cause ... only pain.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Don’t talk to me about pain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: My son died this morning. This hits Jake like a hammer. He looks away, trying to ma sense of this.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He’s ... dead?

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Now do you understand what you've done?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (weakly) God, I’m sorry ...

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: You will be. Jake looks down — The blade of a knife flicks open, catches the light — Jake stumbles back against the bar, crashing into other patrons. Jake scrabbles for purchase ... he falls, bringing the Polynesian lamp from the bar crashing down with him ... P The bulb shatters and the lamp goes dark. His point made, Mr Lim stands over Jake and looks down on him. On the floor, Jake looks wretched, at the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Go on, then ... do it. Lim’s anger seems to fade, leaving only pity for Jake.

dialogues.speaker: MR LIM
dialogues.text: Perhaps a man who believes in nothing is already dead. Mr Lim pushes away through the crowd. Jake looks up, dazed, to see patrons staring down at him. Among them is the Tattooed Punter — he shakes his head in disgust and turns away. Jake frowns, noticing — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BLOOD drips from his clenched fist. He opens it to reveal Samoan tool. Its needle points have bitten deep into his palm. The noise of the bar is pushed into the distance. TAP-TAP ... TAP-TAP-TAP! The sound of the Samoan tattooist at wor Polynesian voices united in song, strangely menacing. We PUSH IN on the lamp lying on its side next to Jake, towards its now dark scene of Pacific kitsch. The sounds tatau in progress intensify ... INT. DREAM — VARIOUS 17 TAP-TAP-TAP! Samoan tattooing tools work dark skin, leavi their dense pattern of ink and blood. A distinctive tapa cloth design. Beyond, flax matting disappears into shadow

dialogues.speaker: TAP-TAP-TAP
dialogues.text: JAKE'S NEEDLE etches the last of the Chinese symbol onto Lim’s son. The young boy’s eyes are open, bloodshot, glaz and dilated. Dead. YOUNG JAKE huddles in the shadows. The boiler’s ticking i indistinguishable from the sound of the tattooing tools. dark figure looms.

dialogues.speaker: DARK FIGURE
dialogues.text: You’ve brought shame on our house. A KNIFE BLADE glows red-hot against the boiler.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (distant, distorted) You seen pain. Only, you ain’t found a way through yours ... The movement of the tattooing tools becomes frenzied. A f clenches in pain ... blood flows ... TAP-TAP-TAP! The lin of pe’a are black, vivid — graphic patterns wrap around t curve of a body in extreme close up — ALIPATI (0.S.) (CONT’D) (distant, distorted) Sometimes it’s right in front of your eyes, brutha. You just gotta —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake opens his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The TAPPING of the tools swirls around him as he sits bol upright on his bed in a shitty, neon-lit hotel room. His chest heaving, Jake looks across to the bedside table, an the tool he stole from the Samoans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booths are being dismantled and packed away. Jake appears a run. He reaches the spot where the Samoan tent was and stops, out of breath. The tent is gone. Jake looks down, to the Samoan tool hel his hand. Fading in, the roar of JET ENGINES ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plane thunders towards the tarmac, landing gear impacti with a squeal. A fully tattooed Maori warrior looks down from a massive that reads: Haere mai ki te whenua o Aotearoa — Welcome t New Zealand. Jake looks up at the sign, impressed. Behind him, the bus of travellers arriving and departing. Jake heads for a li of waiting taxis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAXI DRIVER holds the boot of the car open for Jake to his bags. A swirling Moko design encircles one of his forearms. Jake pulls a LANGUAGES OF THE SOUTH PACIFIC phrasebook fr the pocket of his bag and looks up a word:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Talofa.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) Kia ora. Jake looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (grins) I’m Maori. Not Samoan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake nods, confused. The driver SLAMS the boot closed —

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/CENTRAL AUCKLAND STREET
dialogues.text: A car horn BLARES. SUVs and sedans fight for space, along a multicultural pedestrian tide. Jake watches from inside a taxi. A glimpse of Ta Moko her Samoan tattoo design there — every variation on contempor tattooing, worn openly with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAM! The door closes behind Jake. He stands in an empty motel-style apartment. A short hallway leads towards the bedroom. Jake puts down his bags. Jake slides open the drawer of the bedside table, grabs t BIBLE that lies inside. He throws it in the trash. Jake shaves. Smart-casual clothes hit the bed. Jake butto his shirt. Jake picks up the Samoan tool from the kitchen benchtop. looks down at it, considering ... then puts the tool ina drawer and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaborate signage announces BEDLAM in stylised, manga-sty script. Below, the entrance to what could only be one fuc cool tattoo studio. Jake looks up at the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extensive mirrors create an illusion of depth. TATTOO ART laugh, joke, dance to Japanese punk. The blacks and greys the decor extend to the tattoos, which seem accomplished soulless, generic McTattoos for trendsetters. Jake looks around, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch. Jake turns to see CRASH (mid-30s), American, heavily-tatt and dressed in designer cool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got some serious balls. Jake meets Crash’s glare. The murmur of conversation quel

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Come on, Crash ... forgive and forget, huh? One of Crash’s tattooists, CANINE, approaches, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: CANINE
dialogues.text: Crash ...?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: (to Canine) My first studio. Apple of my eye. This little fucker steals a design off my wall. Embarrassed silence. Jake returns Crash’s gaze, clearly guilty of this offence.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tattoos some South Central hip-hop who-the-fuck-is-this-guy, next thing I know they’re jerking each other off over my fucking design in a sidebar on page seventeen of Tattooist Magazine. Guilty again.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then he trashes my Porsche ... Jake frowns — eh?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ... fucks my dog, steals my AmEx and spends up big at Saks Fifth Avenue. (starts to grin) Lingerie department. (beat) My mother’s size. Jake’s grinning now too. Crash opens his arms.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mere. Jake hugs Crash. The onlookers laugh and return to work.  26 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TATTOOIST MAGAZINE image of a younger Jake mugging alongside a tattooed black man in a baseball cap and blin Jake and Crash sit on comfortable-looking couches in Cras impeccably-designed designer office, the magazine open on coffee table in front of them. Crash is on a roll.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: The Pacific, it’s the heartland of tattooing — the wellspring, the source. The word ‘tattoo’ ... they invented it, the Samoans, the Fijians, those guys. It’s the wellspring — I say that already? And that’s good for my brand value .-».- hell, I just traded in the Boxster for a Bentley. But it don’t make it any of your business.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: Cause it’s not in your blood. This guy Alipati — he’s hard-core, you know that, right? He ain’t just gonna hand generations of tradition down to some kid from Buttfuck, Minnesota who thinks he’s had some kind of epiphany. Jake looks away, frustrated. CRASH (CONT’D) Anyway, the old Jake wouldn’t have asked — he’d have just stolen the designs and made out like he’d been doing Samoan tattoos his whole life.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (grins) Was the old Jake that much of an asshole?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: I kind of liked him. Egocentric. Pissed off. Self-destructive ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Should've been around when he went downhill.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: You know, the only thing that sets one tattoo apart from another is the guy doing the work. Skill - that’s what matters. (beat) Come work for me again.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That’s not what I came here for, Crash.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: Give me two days a week. I’1l throw in the company car.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Crash —

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: The Samoans ain’t gonna teach you shit, bet you anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Can you get me his address or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake gets into the back of another taxi. A SAMOAN DRIVER behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Kia ora.

dialogues.speaker: SAMOAN DRIVER
dialogues.text: Can’t you tell a hori from a coconut, boss?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: SAMOAN DRIVER
dialogues.text: I’m Samoan. We say talofa. Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Otara. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The driver grins as he slams the taxi into gear and pulls into traffic.

dialogues.speaker: SAMOAN DRIVER
dialogues.text: Home sweet home.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/OTARA STREETS
dialogues.text: Jake stares out at the passing landscape. Outside the window, the heart of Auckland’s Pacific Islan community offers sharp contrast to the roar of downtown Auckland. We pass people on the street, booming hip-hop, roaring ca Pylons tower overhead. From the corrugated iron roofs to flowers and Pacific-style clothes, everywhere we look, th landscape seems to burst with the colour of life.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI/OTARA MARKETS
dialogues.text: The taxi pulls up at the edge of a car-park behind Otara shopping centre. The wide expanse of concrete is crowded colourful stalls and vendors, bustling with people. The TAXI DRIVER nods towards the market.

dialogues.speaker: TAXI DRIVER
dialogues.text: In there. Jake follows his gaze, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake heads through the dense throng of the market. He loo around, lost, then glimpses — A red flower. A few metres away, Sina talks to an OLD SAM WOMAN at a fruit stall, the red flower in her hair. Jake watches, mesmerised, as she laughs and hugs the woman, th walks away. Jake follows. Passersby jostle him as he pushes against t flow of the crowd. Jake darts between stalls into another identical row. He spins, trying to get his bearings. The bustling maze of the market closes in on him, trinkets clothes and fruit stalls ...

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lost? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake turns to see Sina watching him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (she points) I think Singapore’s back that way.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Actually, I was looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Your friends, I mean ... you and your friends.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Maybe we should go before you buy something you regret. She leads him through the market, a familiar sound floats above the others: TAP-TAP-TAP ... TAP-TAP-TAP! INT/EXT. ALIPATI’S GARAGE - DAY 31 A back corner of the market, where canvas stalls give way the backs of shops and storage areas. In one of them, Alipati works, his back to Jake. Semo, wh saw being worked on in Singapore sits at the head of anot a young man being tattooed, OPETA, muttering encouragemen Peni and the other guys from the expo hang out on folding chairs and mats.

dialogues.speaker: PENI
dialogues.text: Your girlfriend’s here, cuz. Alipati notices Jake and Sina and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Every expo, there’s some palagi wants to be down with the brown. He gets to his feet as Jake steps nervously to the entran of the stall, a tattooing tool in his hand. He glares at Sina. She shrugs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Laughter. 21. 31

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That stuff I said, I —

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: You came all the way to Otara to apologise? Those suckers must pay you heaps. Jake looks around nervously.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You said what I was looking for was right in front of me ... I didn’t understand. But I do now, and all that other bullshit, it’s finished. I want something real ... I want you to teach me.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: That what you thought I meant?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ever since Singapore, I’ve been thinking about it ... dreaming about it ...

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: I told you, tatau is about more than a living. It don’t start here — (holds up the tool, then taps his chest) It starts here.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I know. I’m ready.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: It ain’t skills you need, brother. Alipati turns away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: But I’ve come a long way!

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Not from what I can see. Jake watches Alipati, helpless. He sighs and turns away. Sina watches as Jake disappears into the market crowd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Sina) You should know better, bringing him here.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know ... there’s something

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: about him, Ali. others. He’s not like the Alipati looks at her sharply.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: You want to go down that road, Sina? Your uncle ain’t gonna like it, that’s for sure ... Sina nods — he’s got that right. ALIPATI (CONT’D) --. and neither do I. Sina meets his gaze ... then runs to catch up with Jake. Alipati watches after her, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Wait up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Sina walk side by side through suburban streets.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Alipati’s old-school, traditional. They say he can see a tatau before he does it. That the spirits tell him what’s supposed to be there. Jake looks down at his scar.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Or what was.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Tatau's his life — he thinks it’s up to him to protect it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: From guys like you.  33 23. EXT. MR VA’A’S HOUSE - EVENING 33 A weatherboard state house among other weatherboard state houses. A large hibiscus bush dominates the front of the house. Jake follows Sina up the path towards the door. He looks across — Inside the house next-door, an elderly Samoan woman cover mirror with tapa cloth.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s she doing?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: She's covering the mirror for the night so bad spirits don’t get her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: I lived with my Grandma for a while in Apia. There was all sorts of things we weren't allowed to do. Whistling inside, brushing your hair or laughing at night.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And you believe all that stuff?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Maybe. I mean, I go to church. But Alipati’s taught me a lot about the old ways.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Best of both worlds, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: For now. They arrive at the porch. SINA (CONT’D) Why did you come here, Jake? To learn tatau from Alipati?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve done things I’m not proud of. And meeting you guys ... it felt like — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What, fate?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That’s not what I — She takes his hand, runs her fingertips across his scar.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: A guy with a scar like this has to believe in something, right? Their eyes meet. Then Jake pulls his arm away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Talk to Alipati for me?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Jake ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t want to take it away from him. It’s his art, and I respect that. All I want to do is watch, and learn.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (at last) Okay. Jake grins.

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now if my uncle comes home from church and finds a palagi boy on the doorstep, he’1ll kick me all the way back to Sa. Literally. Sina disappears inside. Jake looks along the side of the house. The back garden l immaculate, lush, wild with banana palms and flowers. A corrugated iron shed is visible, brooding in the darkness Sina reappears. SINA (CONT’D) Give me a couple of days, I’1l talk to him. But come see me at work, okay? Not round here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hands Jake a piece of paper, then takes the red flowe from her hair and hands it to him, before closing the doo Jake grins, then starts down the path. TAP-TAP-TAP. Jake pauses, listening. TAP-TAP-TAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TAP-TAP-TAP. Jake approaches the shed and cups his hand against a dark window. The sound emanates from the darkne inside. The sound of a car pulling up. Headlights sweep across th lawn. Jake looks around — where to run? A car door SLAMS. CRUNCH ... CRUNCH ... CRUNCH ... the he tread of a man coming up the path towards the house. Jake backs slowly around the side of the shed. A MACHETE leans against the shed wall. Jake kicks it over. The blad clatters against the corrugated iron. Jake freezes. A dark shape on the path — a huge man, his head cocked, massive hands hanging by his sides. He strides towards th shed and pushes the door open. MR VA‘A stands in the shed doorway and peers into the darkness. He wears a faitaga and churchgoing jacket, with silver crucifix around his neck. Mere inches away, Jake cowers against the shed wall. Mr Va‘a closes the door behind him and heads into the hou The door SLAMS behind him. Jake sighs with relief. PAT-PAT. PAT. Jake looks down ... droplets of fresh blood the grass. The wound on his palm is bleeding. TAP-TAP-TAP! The tattooing sound again, from inside. Jake peers through the window ... INT. SHED - NIGHT — DREAM 35 The darkness through the shed window becomes a tunnel, di candlelight in the distance. A man lies face-down on flax mats, moaning softly. A silhouette crouches over him, bony hands working tattooin tools: TAP-TAP-TAP! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A partially-completed pe’a design on the man’s back ... t long, sharp points of an ulalei, a ceremonial necklace of whale-tooth ... Something’s wrong. The man gasps, his breath a deathly rattle. The song begins to waver and crackle, as though playing off an old record. The tattoo cracks and festers fresh lines split and weep. The ulalei is streaked with b and ink. The recipient turns his head — it’s Jake! The hammering intensifies and he tries to ward off the blows. Mighty CL continue as tattooed skin ruptures ... blood and ink run together ... Jake gasps for breath. Blood blooms ... a red hibiscus ... the blood clouds outw -+. a horribly bloodshot eye, its pupil fixed and dilated Jake tries to pull away from the blows. The images merge shift ... the tattooist, the rose tattoo, Mr Lim’s son’s eyes, the nightmare pe’a in progress, the ink, the ulalei the blood, the hibiscus flower — Jake SCREAMS —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake sits up in bed, breathing hard. Lights from the stre dance through the shadows. He opens his hand ... to find Sina’s red hibiscus flower, crushed against dried blood o his palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small bathroom with a large mirror. Behind Jake, a show alcove with a frosted glass door. He bandages his hand, t fills a glass with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first pale rays of dawn creep into the bedroom. A MURMURING UNDERCURRENT of the dream’s cacophony. Jake s on the bed, deep in thought, his gaze fixed on — The red hibiscus, its stem resting in the glass of water, the bedside table. As the dawn creeps towards it, its pet begin to revive.  39 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of buzzing needles fills the air. Crash heads towards an empty workspace, the Tattooist Magazine in han Crash tears out the page with Jake on it and tapes it to mirror, then turns to Jake with a smile of triumph.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Crash, take that down ...

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: There’s the book.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No original designs?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: Get to work. He points. Jake looks across to see LUKE, a Singaporean teenager (18), cool but nerdishly so. Nearby, a young Singaporean woman checks out the images o Bedlam’s work. This is VICTORIA (early 20s). She’s attrac and wearing what looks like a conservatively pretty dress Jake approaches Luke.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, I’m Jake. Victoria turns, holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Victoria. Jake is taken aback to see graphic tattoos snaking out fr under her dress.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Crash says you could be the next big thing.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Which one of you guys ...

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (points to Luke) Oh, Luke, my cousin. Sorry ... Do you mind if I watch? Check out your stuff? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Okay. Luke holds out the Bedlam design book, open to a page. Ja glances at it, then takes the book and closes it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Aren’t you gonna use the book? Jake pulls on his latex gloves.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (quietly) You want something cool or not? Luke grins.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is gonna hurt. You man enough?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m eighteen ... on Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Then I guess you got nothing to worry about. Jake smiles at Victoria. She smiles back, clearly infatua Jake's needle begins to BUZZ ... an outline emerges, geometric shapes ... then deep blocks of colour, richly shaded. Victoria watches Jake intently. His eyes flick to her, conscious of her attention, acknowledging it. Busted, Victoria looks away. Finally, Jake snaps off his rubber gloves. He steps back admire the finished design. It’s discreet but stunning, a to the Bedlam aesthetic but something more, with colour t gives the image a bold luminosity. Luke turns his shoulder towards the mirror and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Where have you been hiding?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Singapore.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: No shit — that’s where we’re from. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake smiles — no shit. LUKE (CONT’D) What were you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Avoiding questions. Use moisturiser every day, keep it out of the sun and try not to get it wet, okay? Luke takes out his wallet. Jake shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: On the house — birthday present.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You serious?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Get outta here before Crash changes my mind. Luke gets off the chair, reaches into his jacket and hand Jake a folded piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I’m having a party on Friday night, my folks’ place. It won’t be lame, they got a pool and stuff. Jake takes the invite. Victoria smiles at him, intent.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He’1l be there. A couple of the Bedlam employees smirk, watching the scen Self-conscious, Jake hands the invite back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I got plans Friday. Victoria shrugs — suit yourself — and leaves with Luke, turning before they reach the door to look back at Jake o last time. Crash appears.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: What is this, a charity or a dating agency? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You gonna take the picture down or not?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A BAND OF TATTOO ART is etched around a large forearm, su echoing the geometric forms of tatau. Jake frowns, looks down. A miniature poodle sits at his f The customer is GRAHAM, a burly league player turned businessman. He wears expensive suit trousers and Italian leather shoes, at odds with his cauliflower ears. Jake leans in to resume the tattoo, then stops again. Graham's trophy girlfriend CHANEL admires him from the counter, her eyes travelling admiringly across his tattoo She chews gum.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I’m getting this for her. Eh, pumpkin? Got a thing about tattooed fellas.

dialogues.speaker: CHANEL
dialogues.text: Graham! Chanel leans down to retrieve the poodle, a manoeuvre cle designed to reveal maximum cleavage. Jake stands back to her room. Jake starts work once again. We look away, to the bustlin studio, as the needle BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: Different customers, different tattoos. Jake’s customer i IVAN, fifties, powerful and wiry — perhaps a former soldi or merchant seaman — with a ZZ-Top beard gone haywire. In groove now, Jake pulls on his gloves.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Petrovich.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Petrovich. Ivan. Three o’clock. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Right. Sawyer, Jake. I'11 be your tattoo artist this afternoon. Jake eyes Ivan’s weathered skin, an encyclopedia of class tattoo designs.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I can some find room on here ..?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: There’s always room. Jake’s needle BUZZES, shapes and defines. Ivan stares int space, his jaw clenched.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: LATER. Business is winding down as Jake clears away his workspace. Crash approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: All this colour, this expressiveness ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: Get in touch with your inner mural artist on your own time. Crash walks away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey Crash, about that car — A jingle of airborne keys. Jake catches them.

dialogues.speaker: CRASH
dialogues.text: Don’t bleed on my fucking merino seat covers. Alarmed, Jake notices that a trickle runs from the bandag his hand, black and thick like ink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immaculate bathroom out the back of the studio. At the basin, Jake pulls away the bandage. Black ink mixes with water and swirls away down the drain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sudden movement in the mirror — a dark figure, barely glimpsed in the reflection. Jake spins, but the room is empty. He turns back to the basin, creeped out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grimy back-alley behind Bedlam Tattoo Studio. Jake star car keys in hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, man ... THE COMPANY CAR is just that: a late-model Japanese impor covered with Bedlam-style tattoo designs — a mobile billb for Bedlam, and seriously uncool.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. JAKE'S CAR/OTARA STREETS
dialogues.text: Jake drives through Otara. He holds the square of paper t Sina gave him. He turns a corner and crawls the kerb, rea the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Nineteen ... twenty-one ... Jake slows the car. JAKE (CONT’D) Twenty-three ... Jesus. Jake looks aghast. It’s a church. INT. CHURCH/ARCHIVE — DAY 43 Storage shelves loom, stacked with boxes and piles of pap Barely organised chaos. OSONE (10) wears cool street clothes, at odds with the de behind his eyes. He fishes a faded photo from a box full old pictures. He studies the faces. He seems both intent the image and distant, as though focussing beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Mr Palauni. He passes the photo to Sina, who looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: How did you know that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Seen him round, eh.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He died before you were born! Sina wears a conservative blouse and skirt as she stacks bulging archival boxes. As she lifts one, the bottom drop out of it and photos spill across the floor. Jake watches from the doorway, amused.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Bugger.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Glad to see you're making an effort to learn the language. Jake kneels and helps Sina put the photos back in the box Osone stares, eyes wide, over Jake’s shoulder — as if loo at someone behind him. Jake follows his gaze — no-one there. He looks back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Osone edges out of the room, as if he’s trying to stay as away from Jake as he can while he does it. Jake shrugs an flips through the pictures: family group shots, people in churchgoing attire and ceremonial dress.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this is what you do when you're not giving scalp massages.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: There’s forty years of South Auckland stories in this room. My uncle’s trying to make sure they don’t get lost.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Looks like you’re the one doing all the work.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: It’s the least I can do to repay him for everything he’s done for me. (checks her watch) (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have to go pick up some more photos. You want to come?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sure. INT. CHURCH HALLWAY — DAY 44 Sina leads Jake down a hallway towards the church foyer. looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If I’d known I was going to church, I'd have worn something less comfortable. Jake pauses, looking through the main doors to the church Glass panels offer a view of the pews and the altar beyon Mr Va'a stands in the aisle, talking with an elderly MINISTER. JAKE (CONT’D) Your uncle, huh?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You’ve met him?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Not really. A middle-aged PARISHIONER approaches Mr Va’a and the Minister. Mr Va’a takes her hands warmly and smiles. She beams at him.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He’s not really my uncle — after my mum died, Mr Va'a’s wife took me in. Now he’s alone, too. But he lets me stay. Va'a turns, looks through the glass. He sees Sina and smi -.. then notices Jake. His smile fades. Jake looks nervou SINA (CONT’D) What about your folks? Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: They’re dead. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sina looks at him differently now, like she understands something about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ragged graffiti has been sprayed across an unpainted wood fence, several of its boards smashed in. A car sits rusti and abandoned in a concrete driveway, weeds growing throu the cracks. Nearby, a letterbox lies on its side. Beyond is a weathered state house, its curtains drawn, it welcome cold. It’s as though someone sucked all the colou out of this corner of Otara. An unseen dog WHINES mournfu an eerie soundtrack to this grim landscape. Jake follows Sina from his car up towards the front door. Sina knocks. The door opens a crack to reveal suspicious eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Malo Mr Perenese, it’s Sina. It opens. MR PERENESE, silver-haired, middle-aged, wearin faded T-shirt over old suit pants, glares at Jake — then softens as he turns to Sina.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: Talofa, Sina. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carpet is threadbare, the wallpaper stained yellow by nicotine. The house feels heavy with neglect. Nooks and crannies disappear into shadow.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: This is my friend Jake.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How you doing? Jake smiles and extends a hand. Mr Perenese takes it for second, barely making eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: (to Sina) You're here for the pictures? I put them in a box for you. Mr Perenese leads Sina away down the hall towards the fro of the house. Jake stands in the hallway, awkward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He picks up an old framed photo, blows off the dust: it l a hundred years old, a Samoan man crouching in ceremonial dress, a traditional whale-tooth ulalei around his neck. A cockroach scuttles across the carpet, into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake steps into the kitchen as the roach scuttles away. A chipped formica table and windows cracked and stained. A simple wooden crucifix hangs on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unnerved, Jake steps back out into the hallway. From the living room, the sound of muffled voices. Jake catches si of something in a room off the hallway: a portrait photo young woman on a shelf above a neatly-made bed. Jake pushes the door open further ... A second portrait, also of a young woman, is revealed. Th another ... and another. Jake pushes the door open furthe A middle-aged Samoan woman, MRS PERENESE, sits in a chair front of a dresser, her lined face reflected in a large, round mirror. She pulls a brush slowly through her long, greying hair. Her eyes swivel to look at Jake in the mirr

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I didn’t mean to ... She regards him with her unblinking stare, eyes empty wit sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey light filters through the drawn curtains. Everything this room seems to languish in its place.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: They’11l be looked after, Mr. Perenese.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: Old memories ... no use to me. Mr Perenese bends to lift a cardboard box. The back of hi shirt rides up, revealing his pe’a beneath. Jake notices with interest. Perenese follows his gaze. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Mr Perenese’s eyes blaze with sudden anger. PERENESE (CONT’D) You get a good look, eh boy?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m a tattoo artist.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: So what? (to Sina, in Samoan) Sina, why you bring this palagi to my house?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He didn’t mean to offend you. Perenese glares from Sina to Jake.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: Take the pictures and go.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. JAKE'S CAR/OTARA STREETS
dialogues.text: Jake drives, Sina next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I thought a pe’a was something to be proud of.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Not for him. One of their kids ran away, years ago, and the community turned their backs on them.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And what, he just accepted that?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He had no choice. It made them look like bad parents — around here that’s a mark of shame. They pull up outside the church. Jake looks up at the crucifix that graces its roof, his expression dark.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Maybe they deserved it. A kid doesn’t run away unless there’s something he’s running away from. Sina watches him, sensing his pain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What happened to you, Jake? Jake's expression darkens.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So, you talk to Alipati?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (sighs) Yeah. Jake, I’m sorry, but he —

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Tell him he can name his price.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Tell him whatever he wants to teach me, I‘’1ll pay it.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Jake, tatau isn’t just some cure you can buy and sell. She gets out of the car and slams the door. She looks bac the window.

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t come back here, okay? Jake watches Sina walk through the church gates. He slams car into gear and throws it into a U-turn. The car swings around — Osone stands right in his path! Jake slams on the brakes. EXT. STREET — DAY 51 Jake leaps out of the car and crosses to where Osone stan in the road. The boy stares at him, unruffled.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Are you okay? I didn’t even —

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: You see him? Jake looks around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Following you round.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There’s no one there.

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Just cause you don’t see no one, don’t mean there ain’t no one there. Osone points. Baffled, Jake follows the boy’s gaze to whe black ink runs freely from the cut on his hand. Hip-hop bass pounds ahead of a sedan as it pulls up besid them. A tinted window rolls down to reveal a large Samoan in his early twenties. Sitting next to him, his brother. Osone’s COUSINS.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: Osone! Osone runs to the car and gets in. The car peels away, ba thumping. Jake watches them go, bewildered. INT. JAKE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 52 Jake enters the apartment and slams the door behind him, expression stormy. The sound of WATER RUNNING. Jake follo it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake steps up to the bathroom door. Inside, someone splas in the shower. He hesitates a moment, then pushes the doo open. Victoria’s head is visible above the shower door, the res her body obscured. She YELPS in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Shit! Jake ducks back outside. He leans against the wall. The w is shut off. Jake peers around the edge of the door. Victoria is dryin herself. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's covered in striking tattoos, the unmistakable Bedla aesthetic. Jake’s eyes widen. He ducks back out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You always take a shower after you sneak into someone's place? Victoria emerges from the bathroom. She’s wearing vinyl pants, boots, a tiny top that reveals every tattoo — she looks ready to enter the matrix. Jake stares.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Only when I’m dirty. There’s Stoli in the freezer ... see if we can’t loosen you up a bit before we go.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Luke’s party, remember? She sweeps past him. Jake watches helplessly. INT. JAKE’S APARTMENT - EVENING 54 Jake and Victoria sit on the couch, drinking vodka on ice Her cigarette trails smoke.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What did you think, the island princess was just going to hand over the Samoan instruction book?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I thought they’d be flattered I wanted to learn from them.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, I think you can do better than a garage in Otara, Mr Tattooist Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I guess I was doing okay before I came here. I was travelling the world. Making money ... Victoria puts her glass down and straddles him, stroking chest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I find naked ambition such an attractive quality in a tattooist. Victoria takes off her top. Jake puts his hands on her wa moves them up towards her bra. She grabs his wrists.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First things first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake's notebook, open on the bed to a sketch of a tribal design. A needle BUZZES. A line of tears runs from the co of Victoria’s eye towards her hair ... a soft MOAN escape her.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Jake frowns, concentrating as he completes ... A tribal design in greys and blacks, encircling Victoria’ belly-button.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ancient Chinese cure for breaking and entering. She hits him playfully. He pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who cares what it means? She kisses him but pulls away, having second thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Let’s get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pool-side barbecue for Luke’s birthday. Teenage BOYS an GIRLS laugh, shout and drink. Some splash in the water. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A few posers sit around in shades and designer clothes, t cool for the pool. Food sizzles on a barbeque that looks like something NASA designed. UNCLE KEN turns the sausages pedantically. Next him, AUNT SUZY watches the kids with barely-contained suspicion. Both look buttoned down, respectable. Someone WHISTLES. The crowd parts and Victoria appears, a bottle of tequila in hand, Jake in tow.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (whispers to Jake) Just play along, okay? Jake looks confused. Aunt Suzy and Uncle Ken glare at Victoria. One of the sausages catches fire.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, Aunt Suzy. She kisses her aunt on the cheek, deliberately leaving a smear of lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE KEN
dialogues.text: Cover yourself up! You want people to think you’re a criminal?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: This is my fiance, Jake — he’s one of the best tattooists in the world. Jake stares at Victoria, astonished. A hand appears, gripping his arm. Jake turns to see Luke, ashen faced, hollow-eyed and desperate. His long sleeved shirt is well buttoned, in contrast to the casual gear of friends.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE KEN
dialogues.text: Your cousin got sense. He know he'd be dead if he come home with one of those ... things! Luke pulls Jake aside.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s up, man? Enjoying your birthday present —

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: I want to get rid of it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A SHOUT as a posse of Luke’s friends closes in. Jake step back as they grab Luke and hoist him up.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, no! NO! Ignoring his shouts, they carry Luke to the pool and thro him in, fully-clothed. Partygoers laugh and cheer. Uncle shakes his head disapprovingly and returns to his sausage Luke surfaces, spluttering. Someone splashes him and he laughs reluctantly. Victoria appears at Jake’s side, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Did you see their faces? Jake watches her, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me you’ve never done something just to piss your folks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake strides down the path towards his car. Victoria foll him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Jake, wait up! Jake pauses, turns on her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Were all those tats freebies, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crowded water, Luke stops moving. He looks around, afraid. He jerks suddenly, as if hit from below. And agai Luke tries to reach the edge of the pool — BANG! He’s pul back into the water. His friends splash and laugh around oblivious to his panic. Again, Luke is hit from below. He goes under and resurfac struggling. The water blooms with black ink. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A girl looks down, noticing the ink. She sees Luke thrash and backs away. Others do the same, scrambling for the ed ANGLE FROM ABOVE as Luke stands in the centre of the exod a black cloud spreading around him. A girl watches, horrified, finding her voice ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake glares at Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I thought you were up for it. That you wanted to have some fun.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That used to be me, Victoria ...

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then what do you want, Jake? Jake meets her gaze — the answer is obvious. Victoria nod

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should go tell her. OFFSCREEN, a girl SCREAMS. Victoria looks back in the direction of the sound.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gotta go. She turns and heads back up the path towards the house. J gets into his car and slams the door. EXT. SUBURBAN HOUSE — NIGHT 60 The water is now completely black. Luke stands alone in t middle of the pool. CHONK! With a jerk, he’s pulled under The kids begin to SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE KEN
dialogues.text: Luke! Uncle Ken jumps into the water. He dives and surfaces, searching, streaked with black ink. Aunt Suzy screams and runs to the edge, Victoria with her (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Uncle Ken lifts Luke out of the water. Luke gasps, his ey wide, choking, clawing.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He’s here! Luke is jerked from his father’s grasp once again and disappears back under. Uncle Ken searches frantically as Aunt Suzy continues to scream. The other kids watch, ashen-faced. Ken stops movi scanning the water as it settles to a glassy black sheet. Luke’s body breaks the surface, face down. Uncle Ken grab him and hauls him to the edge. Two TEENAGERS pull him out lower him onto the concrete. Luke’s head lolls, his eyes lifeless and glazed. Blood and ink stream from his slack Luke’s mother falls across her son's body, wailing. Victo runs up to comfort her. INT. JAKE’S CAR - NIGHT 61 Jake drives, intent, gripping the wheel. Outside, the Auckland streets are a blur. We move in, towards the band on his hand. The surface of the bandage bulges, darkens, seeping black ink. The ink wells, runs down across the smooth arc of th steering wheel ... Black ink drips from the steering wheel onto Jake’s lap. frowns, looks down ... In the shifting glow of passing streetlights, Jake’s hand appear to be covered with intricate Samoan tatau! Jake GASPS ... the car swerves ... a HORN blares! Jake regains control. He looks down at his hands, now unmarked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Suzy SHRIEKS suddenly and pulls away from Luke’s bod horrified — Victoria follows her gaze, gasps in horror — Under Luke’s wet shirt, vivid lines of black spider acros his chest. Samoan tatau! We move in towards the ragged li and shapes.  63 64 65 66 46. INT. JAKE’S BATHROOM - NIGHT 63 The sound of running water. Jake winces as he peels off t bandage. Blood and ink patter into the basin from his suppurating wound. He stares at his hollow-eyed reflection in the mirror, th looks down. For a moment, the inky water leaves spidery, geometric li of black on the white porcelain — the pattern of the pe’a before it’s washed away. Jake frowns ... did I just see t INT. JAKE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 64 Jake falls back onto the bed, the hibiscus flower in his hand. Streetlights parade across the ceiling, merging and shift forming geometric shapes of light and shadow. Jake closes his eyes. The horns, booming subwoofers and h of the street give way to the TIC-TIC-TIC-TIC of the boil ... the TAP-TAP-TAP of tatau.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXT. MR VA’A’S HOUSE - DAY 65 Jake approaches the house, past dozens of cars parked outside. Music emanates from the garden. Hearing the musi Jake hesitates. Then he heads up the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNK! The blade of a machete misses a log of wood and is embedded in the ground. Peni pulls the machete free and l up the wood again. Jake stands at the corner of the house, mouth open, eyes wide. The back yard is filled with people. Hip-hoppers, clean-c young churchgoers, middle-aged couples in lava-lavas and people under sun umbrellas. The focal point is a pig ona spit, a fire under its sizzling belly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Towards the fence, Mr Va’a sits under a sun umbrella, surrounded by other members of the community. Beneath his lava-lava, his legs display dense lines of tatau. A YOUNG BOY approaches him, hands him a drink. Mr Va'a be in thanks, ruffles the kid’s hair. The boy smiles as thou he’s just been blessed. Jake notices Sina standing nearby. He starts towards her Three young Samoan guys block his path — JOE, CHARLIE and DAMON. Joe glares down at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You lost, bro?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m here to see Sina.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don’t think so. Sina appears beside them. She puts a restraining hand on Joe's arm.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Joe, don’t be a dick. Joe holds Jake’s gaze for a moment, then nods. The cousin head back to their beers. Sina glares at Jake, hostile .. then softens.

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So which part of ‘don’t come back’ didn’t you get?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina, listen to me. Jake glances towards the cousins, uncomfortable. They’re still keeping an eye on him. He takes Sina aside. JAKE (CONT’D) You asked what happened to me ... I wanna tell you. Jake looks down at his scar, remembering. JAKE (CONT’D) There are things I’ve never told anyone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Things you've done?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Things that were done to me. He meets her eyes ... A CHEER from the assembled crowd. Semo and Opeta, the two young men we’ve seen being tattooed by Alipati are helped their feet by their friends. They both have newly-complet pe’a. Their short lava-lava reveal the incredible extent of the finished pe’a: from the knees to the middle of the back, beautiful patterns follow the contours of their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You get the pe’a with a friend. It’s like, by sharing your pain, you halve it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What if you don’t finish?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Then you bring shame on yourself and your family. Alipati breaks an egg over Semo’s head and sprinkles coco water over him.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Faalele lau pe'a! Semo grins, looks skyward and roars a SAMOAN WARRIOR'S CHALLENGE. Opeta grins and hugs him. The onlookers clap a cheer, shaking his hand, handing him gifts — food, envelo traditional Samoan mats.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Now they’re men. Mr Va‘a shakes Semo’s hand, gripping his arm with the oth His gaze is powerful, its warmth intense.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: (to Semo, in Samoan) I’m proud of you, boy.

dialogues.speaker: SEMO
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) Thank you, Mr Va’a. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Va'a heads back towards his chair. He pauses, greets Alip As Jake watches, Va’a congratulates Alipati warmly. Alipa seems touched by his gesture, deferential. Sina follows h gaze —

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: My uncle was a tufuga back in the day. Ali was his apprentice.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Why did he stop?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Alipati was ready, and the community needed him more. (beat) You should really pay your respects. It’s his house. Jake eyes Mr Va‘a. Across the garden, Peni chops at the pig with the machete Mr Va'’a passes him, he grabs the machete from Peni and s him how it’s done. HACK! HACK-HACK! Mr Va’a carves into t pig with three brutal chops.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I might wait till he puts down the big pointy thing.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You got a skull on your shoulder. I think you can come say hi to an old man in a skirt. Sina leads Jake across the garden. HACK! Va’a slices another hunk out of the animal’s haunch wields the machete like he was born with it in his hand. Alipati sees Jake coming and steps up to whisper in Mr Va ear. Va’a nods, hands the machete back to Peni.

dialogues.speaker: SINA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uncle, this is Jake Sawyer. Jake, this is Mr Va’a. Jake holds out his hand. Mr Va’a’s gaze travels from Jake outstretched hand, across the tattoos on his arms. At las Va'a smiles warmly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: It is an honour to have you in my house.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The honour’s mine. Mr Va'a takes Jake aside, his manner that of a wise man a to dispense wisdom. Sina watches as Mr Va’a leads Jake away. Alipati steps up beside her.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: I see you made your choice. Sina meets his eyes. His gaze is cold, disapproving.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Alipati tells me you’ve come to Auckland to be a tufuga. Jake listens respectfully to Mr Va’a. MR VA’‘A (CONT’D) Do you know the national motto of Samoa, Mr Sawyer? Jake shakes his head. MR VA‘A (CONT'D) Fa'avaei le Atua Samoa. ‘Samoa is founded on God’. But Samoa was founded long before God arrived. Before that time, everyone had tatau. The pe’a, for men. The malu, for women. It gave them nobility. Pride. It connected them with their tupuaga. It made them strong. Then the missionaries came to Samoa. And there was no dancing allowed anymore. No singing Samoan songs. And no tatau. But we kept it alive, even though some of our people thought they were going against God by getting a tatau. People like me believed that you could worship God without sacrificing your culture, your birthright. It was hard. But tatau is still here, and getting stronger. (beat) And you come over here and expect us to hand it all back to you again? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m not a Christian, Mr Va'’a.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Nor are you Samoan. (beat) Sina will show you some hospitality. Eh, Sina? Look after our guest ... until it’s time for him to leave. She nods, leads Jake away. Mr Va’a watches after them.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The sun sits low to the horizon, draining the warmth from afternoon. Jake and Sina sit at the edge of the section and drink fr plastic cups. Across the garden, kids pack up deck chairs umbrellas.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So much of this ... I don’t know if I’1l ever understand. It’s like another world. Maybe Alipati’s right not to teach me.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He was wrong about one thing: you have come a long way. (beat) What did you want to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Can we go somewhere else?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: I guess you’ve seen my world ... how about you show me where you're from?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THUNK! The machete hits the ground again beside a log of wood.

dialogues.speaker: PENI
dialogues.text: Fuck! Peni pulls the blade free and lines up another go. Sina appears at his side. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Try closing one eye?

dialogues.speaker: PENI
dialogues.text: Real funny. What you want, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Peni approaches Mr Va'a, who is supervising the cleanup o his house.

dialogues.speaker: PENI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr Va'a? My grandma’s sick. She needs someone to look after her tonight while I’m at work.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Take Sina with you. (shouts to Sina) Sina! You go with Peni tonight, look after his grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Yes, uncle. Peni passes Sina, on his way inside. He gives her the nod mission accomplished. She nods back — owe ya one.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. MOTORWAY/JAKE'S CAR
dialogues.text: The sun sits low over the hills. The city is golden as Ja and Sina drive towards it. Jake looks over at Sina. She sits back in her seat and sm at him. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake shows Sina into the dark shop. Mirrors reflect their silhouetted shapes against the passing lights of the road Sina looks at the designs on the walls of the shop.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I used to dream about this, when I was starting out. My own place ... my own designs. A few regulars.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What do you dream about now? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t want to know.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (nods towards his tattoos) I want to see them. Jake takes off his shirt. Her eyes travel across his skin She reaches out to touch an old-school tattoo on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Crash gave me that, in San Francisco. I was celebrating — my first job, my first paycheck. (sadly) I felt like I could do anything. Jake closes his eyes as Sina runs her fingers across his back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got that in Berlin. I was cold. Broke. I loved it. Sina laughs. She reaches down, running her hand across th pale ridge of his scar.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAM! A man’s hand grabs Young Jake’s wrist, wrenches the around to reveal the fresh rose tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You’ve brought shame on our house. The TIC-TIC-TIC of the boiler, close. Jake is pinned in t dark corner. The knife blade is heated against the hot metal until it glows.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was thirteen. My father was a Lutheran minister ...

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your flesh is my flesh, your blood is my blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The blade flashes —

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He was ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We will not defile the temple of the lord! The dark shape of JAKE’S FATHER bends over Jake to work t knife. Young Jake looks up in terror as a heavy gold CRUCIFIX dangles in front of his face, swinging as his father saws his flesh.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Pray with me boy. Pray with me. ‘Our father who art in heaven ...’ Father steps back, holding up the ragged, dripping strip Young Jake’s flesh. SCREECH! He pulls open the iron door the boiler — Young Jake’s eyes widen — As his Father casts the tattoo into the boiler and SLAMS door closed. TIC-TIC-TIC-TIC ... INSIDE, the raging glow consumes Jake’s flesh as the tick of the boiler continues around us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake’s expression is cold, hard. Sina looks appalled.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I left after that. I never went back. Sina kisses him gently on the side of his neck. She close her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: I want a tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Won't they be angry if you get a palagi tattoo? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: This isn’t for them. This is for me.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: The tufuga decides.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: An expanse of Sina’s golden skin seems to glow in the dim light. Jake runs his hands across her back, tracing the contours of her body, judging the right place for the per design. Jake's needle begins to buzz. Sina grits her teeth, takes pain. Jake focuses ... a distant TAP-TAP-TAP joins the BUZZING his needle ... the sounds continue over —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sterile embalmer’s preparation room, deep in shadow. To are laid out, next to a chart and several reference photographs of Luke. Machines switched on. BAMF! An overh light illuminates — A body, under a sheet. The sheet is spotted with blooms o black in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake's needle shapes, hones, defines ... a huge design ta shape, its scope as yet unrevealed ... TAP-TAP-TAP ... INT. GRAHAM’S HOUSE - DAWN 73 A bottle of sleeping pills on a dresser ... moving to fin Chanel, Graham’s girlfriend, asleep under a pink eye mask She turns over, onto a pool of glistening black on peach- coloured satin sheets. She pulls off the eye-mask, frowni peels back the sheet with a wet slurping noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake colours in a section of Sina’s tattoo, blood-red ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His preparations complete, the EMBALMER pulls back the sh from Luke’s head ... and recoils violently at some horror unseen. Luke’s hand slips, dangling from under the sheet. It is covered now in Samoan tatau — even Luke’s fingernails hav been tattooed. Beyond, we can see that the tatau covers t body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake's needle paints a thick, dark curve along Sina’s shoulder blade ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tattooing sounds continue as Chanel follows a slick t of glistening black gloop across the carpet towards a clo en suite door. She looks down ... Black squelches up between her toes from the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: CHANEL
dialogues.text: Baby Gray ... what are you doing in there? Frightened now, she pushes the door open slowly, revealin trail of glistening black ink on white marble, a spreadin pool at Graham’s motionless feet ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Sina make love on the couch in Crash’s office, h new tattoo almost luminous in the glow of the dancing lig from the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The images reach crescendo: needle on skin, skin on skin, ink, sweat and blood ... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: the ink splattered floor of Graham’s bathroom ... the ink stains on the sheet covering Luke bloom and spread ... Chanel finally finds her voice, and SCREEEEEEEAMS — And we see the completed tattoo on Sina’s back: A RED HIBISCUS FLOWER painted in vibrant colour — Jake’s boldes work yet, undeniably influenced by everything he has seen learned. The graphic image dissolves to ... THE HIBISCUS FLOWER from before, now wilted and lifeless its glass beside Jake's bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — as Jake and Sina lie back, entangled, their breathing slowing, calm returning as the chaotic sounds ebb.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Why did you tattoo those people, if you didn’t share their beliefs? For the money?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Because they’re pathetic ... they’re weak.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: It’s not weak to have faith.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It is when you hide behind it ... use it to hurt people.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Did you ever think maybe your father was scared? And maybe now he’s somewhere where he doesn’t have to be anymore? Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He lives in Wisconsin, in the house I grew up in. I haven’t spoken to him in ten years.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: My parents are dead. I can’t ever make that pain go away. But it’s not too late for you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake stares at the ceiling, his expression dark, conflict

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
