dialogues.text: Jake stirs, restless. In the darkness, Sina MOANS softly. Jake looks over at her. She frowns, twitches, eyes dartin under her lids — in the grip of a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Sina stand on the footpath outside Bedlam.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Can't you stay?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: If I’m not at church, people will ask questions. Jake looks disappointed. SINA (CONT’D) One step at a time, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So all that stuff about this not being for them ... about it being for you ...

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: It’s for both of us. She kisses him, then pulls away. He watches as she walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake enters, slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Victoria is standing in the shadows at the end of the roo

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You can’t keep ... (CONTINUED)
83 He trails off at the sight of her: drawn and haggard look

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shit, are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Luke’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: My aunt and uncle’s pool. In five feet of water ... in front of thirty people.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That’s terrible.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It was a birthday present. I wanted him to be cool ... not dead.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: He was covered in tattoos. Tattoos that weren’t there two days ago. Jake frowns.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were all over him, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Tattoos don’t just do themselves.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then who did them, Jake? Did he come back for more? Cause I’ve been thinking about it and thinking about it and I just can’t see how else this happened.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Victoria, whatever happened, it was nothing to do with me.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: My uncle’s calling the Health Department. He wants to press charges against Bedlam. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Jake snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) I said there was always room. But there’s not a lot left now ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) You started it, boy ... and now he’s nearly finished it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (thinks hard) Ivan? CLICK! The line goes dead. Jake stares at the receiver, stunned. He grabs the phone book, rifles through.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peters ... Peterson ...

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Jake, did you hear what I said? They think it’s your fault.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Petrovich! Jake slams the phone book shut and heads for the front do

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Who was that on the phone? Jake, I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It was another guy I tattooed. And he’s gone. She looks away, her mind racing ... 84 EXT. JAKE’S APARTMENT - DAY 84 Tyres squeal as the Bedlam car pulls away from Jake’s apartment.  85 86 87 88 89 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria steps into the bathroom and turns on the light. stares blankly at her wretched reflection in the mirror, looks down, steeling herself. She pulls up her top. Her eyes widen in horror. EXT. BLOCK OF FLATS — DAY 86 Jake slams his car door outside a large block of council flats in a tree-lined street. The windows make a ragged patchwork of curtains, washing and wall hangings. INT. STAIRWELL — DAY 87 Jake races up the dirty, glass walled stairwell. Reflecti of himself surround him, shifting and moving as he climbs INT. BLOCK OF FLATS — DAY 88 Jake emerges on an upper landing and searches the apartme doors. He stops at one. All the curtains are closed. Jake bangs on the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ivan? It’s Jake! Silence. He bangs again. The door swings open. Jake steps inside. INT. IVAN’S FLAT — DAY 89 Jake peers into darkness.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hello? Jake creeps into the living area. The room is trashed, as a struggle has taken place. A large mirror on the wall is cracked, streaked with ink.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calls) Ivan! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CRUNCH. Jake looks down — he has stepped on the broken remains of a light bulb. He looks up — the bulb has been crushed in its fitting. A thick breath from the darkness. Jake wheels. A dark sha sits in the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ivan? Jesus ... The figure laughs, quickly breaking into a hacking wet co Jake crosses to the windows and reaches for the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s get some light —

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: Don't! Jake pauses. A thin shaft of daylight streams in. Ivan huddles, rocking gently, an inky shadow. Only the wh of his eyes catch the light. He leans forward, the light catches a narrow strip of skin. Ivan is so covered in pe’ that he seems black. Only tiny fragments of pale skin rem visible.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The space between the points ... it’s the killing space ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: He’s finishing what you started. (clicks his tongue) TIC-TIC-TIC ... TIC-TIC-TIC ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who did this to you? Ivan rises slowly out of his chair, bones creaking.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: The ‘au ... the sausau ... Ivan moves through the shaft of light, revealing more gha detail on his naked old body. Woven into the pe’a are the tattoos that already covered him, including Jake’s. Ivan mutters in guttural Samoan: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) .-. the ink ... the shame that drives my fury ... Jake backs away towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’1l get doctors. Ivan reaches out a blackened hand, the flesh of his arm withered and wet. The ridges and patterns gleam in the li

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: (starts to laugh) Flay my bones ... my black heart bare ... Ivan’s tattooed face leers into his, blackened teeth visi behind tattooed lips. Ivan pauses ... then looks towards the mirror, SCREAMS — Jake wheels, catching a fleeting glimpse of a dark, wiry shape as it sweeps across the broken glass.

dialogues.speaker: IVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s coming again!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who? Ivan starts to sing under his breath in Samoan — the lilt song from Jake’s dreams. TAP-TAP-TAP! The sound reverbera around them. Jake grabs Ivan’s wrists, trying to snap him of it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ivan, WHO’S COMING?!

dialogues.speaker: IVAN
dialogues.text: He’s finishing ... what you started! Ivan lunges, GROWLING. His skin breaks apart under Jake’s fingers, flesh seeping black ink. Jake gasps in horror an stumbles back towards the door. He claws at the handle an wrenches it open ...  90 91 92 64. INT. BLOCK OF FLATS — AFTERNOON 90 Jake stumbles through the door and races away from the fl The door slams shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake crashes into his apartment. He slams the door behind and locks it. He picks up the phone and dials frantically, waits.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Come on, Sina ... pick up ... He stops. The sound of WATER RUNNING. Jake frowns, replac the receiver. Jake creeps tentatively through the apartment towards the bathroom. Steam billows out into the hallway. Water sprea out across the floor in a dark stain. Water puddles around his feet, mixed with black ink. The forms the intricate filigrees of a pe’a design, then dissolves. Jake pushes the bathroom door open ... INT. APARTMENT BATHROOM — DAY 92 A pale figure is ghosted behind the glass: Victoria. She looks up at him, her eyes bloodshot.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) Victoria ... He looks down ... the water swirling around her feet is black! Alarmed, Jake pulls the door open — Her belly is a ragged black wound. Black ichor and blood spill down her legs to bloom in the water. Her hand comes slowly and uncurls to reveal STEEL WOOL and fingers black with ink. Victoria looks up through her hair, mouth open in wordles horror. She trembles, gasps ... and SCREEEEEEEEAMS!  93 94 95 65. INT. JAKE’S CAR - DAY 93 Jake drives frantically. Victoria moans from the back sea She's wrapped in a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hold on! He looks to the rear view mirror — and glimpses a wiry sh in the back seat, looming over Victoria — TAP-TAP-TAP! Ja slams on the brakes and the car screeches to a halt. He t to look — Victoria writhes in pain. Ink smears the seats. She is al

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It huuuurrrrrrttttts! Jake slams the car into gear and peels away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake's car pulls up with a squeal outside Accident and Emergency. He jumps out, throws open the back door and li out Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake carries Victoria through the doors. The sheet is twi around Victoria's body and sodden with blooms of black in line of ink drips onto the gleaming lino.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Somebody — we need help! He staggers toward the reception desk. Victoria begins to slip from his arms, the sheet pulling around her. Jake dr to his knees. A NURSE comes running.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She's ... sick. The nurse pulls at the sheet. Ink puddles out and spreads across the floor. The nurse recoils in horror, looking do at the ink on her fingers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: JAKE (CONT’D) Please help her.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: (shouts) Doctor Faleauto! The nurse backs away from Jake and Victoria. Beyond, othe PATIENTS in the waiting room have risen to their feet, horrified. A MATRON appears, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: MATRON
dialogues.text: (to the Nurse) What is it?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Black slime runs from Victoria’s mouth. Her eyes roll. DOCTOR FALEAUTO, a young Samoan attending physician, and SECOND NURSE run up, pushing a gurney.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: On three. One ... two ... three —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! Led by Dr Faleauto, a posse of doctors and nurses b through double doors into the emergency area. Victoria writhes on a gurney, ink already soaking into the mattres The gurney leaves a trail of black ink across the floor. follows the grisly caravan.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: What’s her name?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Victoria, can you hear me? How long have you been feeling sick? She lurches, coughs a torrent of black ink over the medic team. It streaks their hospital whites.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Ask ... him... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Have you taken any drugs, Victoria? Do you have any allergies? Jake stands helpless, devastated, as they push the gurney into a trauma room. INT. TRAUMA ROOM — DAY 97 A SECOND DOCTOR and more NURSES have joined those hoverin over Victoria on the table. A nurse vainly tries to staun the black ink discharging from Victoria’s belly. Victoria’s tattoo snakes out of the wound and covers her chest and shoulders — her own stylised classic imagery br down and distorted by the pe’a motif. Jake hovers, stricken. Victoria grabs his arm, her grip strong, her fingertips leaving black smears on his skin.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Jake ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What happened to Luke ... not you -.. him. Her eyes roll back, eyelids fluttering. The doctors push aside.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: B.P. sixty over forty and dropping.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Get a line in. Push twenty of epi. A nurse tries to find a vein in her arm with a shaking ha A needle pierces flesh. The skin breaks apart, dischargin thin sheet of ink that washes down Victoria’s tattooed ar onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NURSE
dialogues.text: Trouble finding a vein.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Come on!

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Twenty epi in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NURSE
dialogues.text: Okay, got it! Jet black liquid streams into the clear tube from Victori arm. SECOND NURSE (CONT’D) Oh my god ...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Get that out. What have you hit?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: B.P. fifty over thirty. Still dropping.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: (to Jake) Has she been overseas? How long has she been sick?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. BEEP-BEEP-BEEP-BEEP-BEEP-BEEP — a shrill alarm goes off.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: She's arrested.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Another twenty epi. Charge paddles to one-eighty and clear.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Paddles one-eighty. She hands the doctor the defibrillator paddles.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NURSE
dialogues.text: Twenty epi in.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Clear, dammit!

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Clear.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Clear. The doctor places the paddles against Victoria’s chest — WHUMP! She jolts horribly. Another torrent of ink spills her mouth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NURSE (CONT’D) Still down.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Charge two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Clear! WHUMP! The lights spark above Victoria. The room flickers and out of darkness. Amid the frantic medical staff is another shape, glimpsed between light and shadow — THE TATTOOIST, crouched over Victoria, his back to Jake. broken, infected-looking pe’a twists up the Tattooist’s b In one hand he grasps a bloody bone chisel, in the other hammer. TAP-TAP-CLANG! The Tattooist’s hammer falls, spraying ink

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There! Can’t you see him? The doctors continue work on Victoria, oblivious to the spectre upon her. WHUMP! The lights flicker on again, and the Tattooist is gone. Victoria is lifted off the bed by the defibrillator her back arched.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Charge two-ten. (indicates Jake) Get him out of here! A nurse SCREAMS. CLANG! CLANG-CLANG! In three violent jol one of the few areas untouched by the pe’a is filled in b with brutal accuracy. The medical team freezes for a mome stunned. Dr Faleauto looks at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Two-ten. Clear?

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Clear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Doctor positions the paddles, pushes them down — SPLU His hands break through Victoria’s chest, disappearing IN the cavity. Tattooed ribs point up around the Doctor’s wr as black liquid wells around them. The Doctor yelps and wrenches his hands free, leaving the paddles immersed in her chest, wires trailing. He stagger away, mewling, horrified. Victoria breaks down as the tatau consumes her before the eyes. Her flesh sloughs away to reveal organs black with pe’a, themselves losing cohesion and dissolving into ink. Two nurses are screaming now. They cower at the end of th room. Jake watches in horror as Victoria bangs and thrashes on table as black ink sprays from her mouth. Her flesh colla into itself as her torso falls away. Ink drips off the be onto the floor. Dr Faleauto steps back as the other medics panic around h

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: (calmly) Quarantine procedure. Nobody leaves. Jake looks around at their horrified faces, then starts backing away. DR FALEAUTO (CONT’D) Security! SECURITY! Jake pushes through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake slips on the shiny floor, leaving inky footprints as runs away down the corridor. Dr Faleauto crashes through doors behind him, his whites sprayed with black.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Security — stop him! A SECURITY GUARD blocks the way. Jake wheels, ducks down passage. The doctor follows. Round a corner, down a passage. A stairwell — Jake takes three at a time. Jake runs down a long corridor and round corner. He looks back — he’s lost his pursuers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans against the wall, panting. The full horror hits hard and he loses it, shaking. His breath catches in his throat ... he bites down on his knuckles. FOOTSTEPS, and Dr Faleauto rounds the corner. Snapping ou it, Jake runs. He follows the passage down, around anothe corner, past a closed fire escape — A dead end! Jake spins, heads back towards the fire escap Doctor Faleauto steps up to challenge him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Please ...

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Took my brother six weeks to get his pe’a. Nearly killed him. Never thought I’d see someone get one in six minutes.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There’s no time.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: You said ‘can you see him’. See who?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Do you believe in spirits? The doctor stares at him, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: You think a spirit did this?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There’s another one ... a girl, in Otara. You have to let me go. The doctor narrows his eyes, considering this. JAKE (CONT’D) I have to get to her, find a way to stop this, or she'll die. Then he steps aside. Jake pushes open the door. As he ste through, Dr Faleauto puts a hand on Jake’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: DR FALEAUTO
dialogues.text: Whatever you’ve started, don’t bring it back here. This isn’t something doctors can cure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake meets his eyes, then nods and disappears through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sina sorts through the box of photos she got from Mr Perenese. Taking out a photo, she frowns ... The photo is of the Perenese family, posing in front of t church. Mr Perenese stands proudly in the centre of a gro composed of his wife, his four daughters and ... the edge the photo has been torn away. CRREEEEEAAAAAK-BANG! A door slams closed somewhere outsid the office. Sina goes to the archive door.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (calls) Is someone there? No reply. Spooked, Sina returns to her desk and continues sorting the pictures. A dark shape fills the doorway behind her. She senses som there, turns —

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: They’re dead. Jake stands just inside the door, his face haunted. He’s covered in grisly splatters of ink.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He killed them. Luke and Ivan ... Victoria. Everyone I tattooed. Ever since I hurt myself with this. He holds out the tool he took from the Samoans in Singapo

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: This is Alipati’s ... Jake, you can’t keep this.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I would have given it back, only I was afraid he wouldn’t teach me! (beat) They couldn’t see him, but I could «+. I could see him killing her! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He’s skinny, with long hair. He looks sick ... his pe’a’s bleeding. His eyes ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You’ve seen him too.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: It was just a dream ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sina stands in front of the mirror, Jake behind her. She unbuttons her top, then pauses ... she looks, in the mirr to Jake ... And pulls off her top. Jake’s eyes widen as he looks at her back. Slowly, fearfu she turns to look at her reflection. Fine lines of raw, b tatau spider outwards from the hibiscus flower — the beginnings of the nightmare pe’a.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina —

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Days? Silence, then:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hours. Sina’s horror is mounting. Jake moves to comfort her. JAKE (CONT’D) Sina, I‘’ll — WHAP! Sina slaps him, again and again. Jake accepts the blows.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: I trusted you!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I didn’t know! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Stay away from me! INT. CHURCH FOYER — NIGHT 101 Sina runs down the hallway towards the church doors. Jake chases after her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina, wait —

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Alipati and my uncle were right — I should never have gotten involved with you! He grabs her, holds her tight. She struggles —

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I promise I’1l help you. She stops struggling and meets his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You promised to ‘help’ those other people, too, but you didn’t really believe it. Why should I believe you now? That hits Jake where it hurts. She pushes through the doo into the church. INSIDE, Sina runs up the centre aisle and stumbles in fro of the altar. The MINISTER hurries over to her. Jake moves to follow — Mr Va’‘a gets up from the front row of pews and stands ov Sina. She looks up at him, her face streaked with tears. Jake hesitates. He takes the tattooing tool out of his pocket, steeling himself ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark in the shopping centre, shops closed. A few groups o youths drink, smoke and laugh. Jake hurries through the shadows, looking back over his shoulder. A car revs sudde the nitro kicking in, and Jake jumps in fright. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He reaches the door of Alipati’s garage. A light inside. knocks, frantic. After a few moments, Alipati opens the d and regards him, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: What you want this time? Singing lessons? Jake opens his hand, shows Alipati the tool. Alipati’s ey widen as he takes it. ALIPATI (CONT’D) You take anything else? Shirt off my back maybe? Or is that everything?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) There’s more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SINA’S TATTOO has spread further. Mr Va’a looks at it closely, his eyes following every line of the expanding p design.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Uncle, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: VA'A
dialogues.text: Cover yourself up. Sina does. She faces him, trembling, terrified ... pleadi Va'a watches her, compassionate, saddened.

dialogues.speaker: VA'A, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife and I, we never had children. You are the closest I have to a daughter ... and I’m so ashamed. Sina crumbles, tears spilling down her face. Va’a, too, l deeply aggrieved.

dialogues.speaker: VA'A, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You run around with this palagi ... embarrass me in front of everyone. And now he give you the pe’a, not the malu as a woman should have?

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He didn’t — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VA'A
dialogues.text: You hate me this much? She shakes her head, devastated, lost.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Uncle, I don’t hate you.

dialogues.speaker: VA'A
dialogues.text: You know I should turn my back on you. How will they forgive this? He is crying now.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do? Va'a takes the silver crucifix from around his neck. His shakes as he holds it out to her.

dialogues.speaker: VA'A
dialogues.text: Same as the rest of us — pray to God, that he will show you the way. Sina stares at the cross, undecided ...

dialogues.speaker: VA'A, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the only way. Sina’s trembling hand closes around the crucifix. INT. ALIPATI’S GARAGE - NIGHT 104 Jake sits on the couch, his head in his hands. Alipati pa muttering. He looks down at Jake and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: I’ve worked for years to make people see tatau for what it is. Pride. Honour. A birthright for all Samoans. But there’s always people like you, come along and think they can take without asking —

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I did ask.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: And I said no! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If I can find out what this spirit wants, maybe I can —

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: What? Take him to Mickey D’s and buy him a Happy Meal? Jake faces up to Alipati, his fists balled. Then he backs down.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen how they die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sina sits hunched in the front row of the church. Around the sound of singing from the assembled congregation. Sin mouth moves in muttered prayer. Beyond the hymn, an undercurrent of TAPPING. Sina’s praye falters.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: First the sounds, the visions ... the tattoo, it grows. Then the ink, from everywhere, like blood. A cough wracks Sina and she doubles over, her hand going her mouth. As the spasm subsides, she looks down in horro «+. to see flecks of black ink on her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She’1l scream and beg for the end ... INT. ALIPATI’S GARAGE - NIGHT 106 Now Jake has Alipati’s full attention.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: ... and then she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: This spirit’s doing this to people you tattoo, right? Jake nods. (CONTINUED)
106 ALIPATI (CONT’D) Then I’1l make this real easy — get your arse on the next plane out of here, and don’t tattoo anyone else. (beat) Ever.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: But she'll die.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Maybe ... maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You know something, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: This ain’t your lookout, brutha.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Listen, whether you like it or not, my eyes are open now.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: That right? Then how come you still stumbling round in the dark? (beat) Now get out of my garage. EXT. ALIPATI’S GARAGE - NIGHT 107 SLAM! Alipati slams the door behind Jake. Frustrated, Jak kicks over a rubbish bin.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ain’t you never heard of ‘be a tidy Kiwi’? Jake turns to see Osone’s two cousins hanging out beside their car. Jake recognises them, approaches. They watch h coolly.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: The other day, there was a kid with you.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: Dunno what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Come on ... he said someone was following me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OSONE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Skinny fella. Dead as. Jake turns to see Osone, a skateboard in his hand. He nod

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I need to know what he wants. Can you ... ask him?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Nup. (beat) You can aks him your own self. But that’1l cost ya. The cousins grin.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Fiddy bucks. For me and my cousins.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Fiddy?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Each. INT/EXT. COUSINS’ CAR/MOTORWAY - NIGHT 108 Jake sits in the back seat of the car, Osone next to him. seat is covered with clear plastic. Hip-hop bass pounds around them. Osone’s two cousins are crammed into the front seat, eyes straight ahead as they drive.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Louder. The cousin in the passenger seat turns up the radio. Jake cringes as the bass gets even louder. He looks outsi to see the towering street lamps of the Auckland motorway passing at speed. Osone closes his eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OSONE (CONT’D) Louder. INT. OSONE’S COUSINS’ CAR - NIGHT 109 Cringing, deafened, Jake looks around anxiously as the ba reaches earth-shattering proportions. Lights seem to fly the window. Jake grips the door, his knuckles white. Osone’s eyes dart under his eyelids. A thin line of blood trickles from one of his nostrils. Suddenly, the pounding bass is obliterated as a burst of STATIC rips through the car, a deafening pulse of white n that oscillates with an undercurrent of angry whispering. The cousin driving the car brakes hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car slams into a sharp skid, sliding sideways onto th hard shoulder and coming to a stop. A car behind swerves around it, laying on the horn. INT. OSONE’S COUSINS’ CAR - NIGHT 111 The roar of whispers is deafening. Jake blocks his ears. Osone convulses. Spots of blood flick from his nose and e splattering the plastic covering the car’s interior. Terrified, Jake tries to hold him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s happening ..?! The cousins watch impassively from the front seat as Oson convulses. His hand whips out and grabs Jake’s arm, vice- like. His voice booms — an adult voice. Multiple lines of song overlap in a distorted, hair-raising cacophony:

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: O Le Tatau A Victoriaoa/I le mafuaaga lenei na iloa/I le taaga o le tatau i Victoriaoa/O le malaga a teine e toalua ...

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What’s he saying? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: Something about tatau.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to Osone/Tattooist) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: (Samoan) I am the ‘au and the sausau ...

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: The tattooing tools!

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: (Samoan) I am the singer and the song ...

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: The singer and the song.

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: (Samoan) The killer and the dead ...

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: The killer and the dead!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: (Samoan) To kill.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: He says he wants to kill.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Why? The Tattooist’s roar shakes the car!

dialogues.speaker: OSONE/TATTOOIST
dialogues.text: (in English)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are you ashamed of? The static seems to reach a crescendo as The Tattooist’s echoes around them — (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TELL ME
dialogues.text: BOOM-BOOM-BOOM ... the static gives way to deafening hip- once again. The cousin in the passenger seat flips off th radio. Silence descends. Osone sits up. He wipes blood off his upper lip.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get him back — I’m not finished!

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: Can't do that, brother — he’s just the smaller, eh.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER COUSIN
dialogues.text: _ (giggles) Like a medium — but smaller! The cousins crack up at the joke.

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: You can’t boss those ones around, eh. They’re pure. Angry — that’s it. You wanna try bossing round a thunderstorm? Or ... a piece of wood?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Okay, I get it, I get it. So what am I supposed to do now?

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Quit your job?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I already got that advice for free.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER COUSIN
dialogues.text: Tatau ain’t really our field of expertise, eh.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: (to Driver Cousin) You were too chicken to get yours, eh?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER COUSIN
dialogues.text: Shut up! Jake’s mind is racing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Take me to church.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN
dialogues.text: Sweet as. For twennie bucks.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER COUSIN
dialogues.text: And petrol money. Jake digs in his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: OSONE
dialogues.text: Man upstairs ain’t gonna help you out.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It’s his flock I want to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Minister stands before the congregation. The churchgo are on their feet, united in song. Their voices soar towa the heavens. At the front of the congregation, Sina sits with her head bowed over Va’a’s silver crucifix necklace. Her eyes are closed as her lips move in prayer. A HAND on her shoulder mr Va’a, standing next to her, singing loudly. BANG! The church doors swing open, framing Jake. At the pulpit, the Minister stops in mid-song. Churchgoer follow his gaze, including Mr Va’a. Sina looks up, dazed shock and fear. The song peters out as Jake strides down the aisle. By th time he reaches the front, a blanket of shocked silence h descended. All eyes are on Jake. Mr Va‘a steps into the aisle, a hand on Sina’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: You are not welcome in this house.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Please ... tufuga. Mr Va‘a is taken aback at Jake’s deference. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An angry spirit is using me to kill. If I can learn who he is, I might be able to stop him. The churchgoers mutter to each other — what’s he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Don’t bring your palagi nonsense in here.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina, show them.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: She doesn’t need your help. Sina looks up at him, the crucifix clutched in her hand. doesn’t look so sure. MR VA‘A (CONT'D) (to Sina) You tell him, you place yourself in God's hands tonight. She gets to her feet. MR VA‘A (CONT'D) Sina!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina, please ... trust me. Mr Va'a steps close to Jake and Sina, his voice lowered, heavy with shame. The community listens with bated breath

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: You have damned her body, boy — will you take her soul as well?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sina, God can’t stop this ... but I can. Sina looks between them, making up her mind.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Uncle, I’m sorry ...

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: You are not my Aiga. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She meets Va'a’s gaze, devastated ... then steps past him into the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Show them. She raises her top, revealing her tattoo to the congregat In the congregation, a WOMAN in her late 20s stands with HUSBAND. Her eyes widen with recognition, her hand goes t her mouth. She looks around for support. Mr Va'a’s expression roils with barely contained fury. Hi fists clench tight and release, clench and release. JAKE (CONT’D) (to the congregation) The spirit who did this will continue, until she’s dead ... or until his shame is ended.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: (to the congregation) No, this is our business! Up the back, the woman’s husband places his hand on her a

dialogues.speaker: HUSBAND
dialogues.text: (sotto) Let Mr Va’a deal with this.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to Va'a) You turn your backs on people you're ashamed of. But if you turn your back on her, it’s you who should be ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Uncle, please let them speak.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: (roars) I said LEAVE! Mr Va'a faces the Minister. He starts to sing, loudly, confidently. Around Jake and Sina, the congregation joins uncertain at first, until the church is once again filled with song. Sina takes Jake’s hand and begins to drag him down the ai towards the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: YOU CAN’T JUST LET HER DIE! The woman in the congregation watches Jake and Sina pass. looks around, catches the eye of some of the others. They encouragement — go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake bursts through the church doors, supporting Sina. As they stumble away from the church, Sina staggers and goes down on her knees, retching ink. Jake kneels to cradle he desperate.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (disoriented) I can see him... The church door opens behind them. Jake looks up — The woman from the congregation, standing at the top of t steps. She looks desperately down at them, as though abou speak. Her husband appears behind her and grabs her arm roughly. She looks up at him and he shakes his head — no. Jake remembers — INT. PERENESE HOUSE — DAY — FLASHBACK 114 The bedroom door creaks open to reveal a photo of a young woman on the shelf behind the Pereneses’ bed ... then the next photo, then the next ... and finally the last Perene daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recognition hits Jake as the woman’s husband pulls her ba into the church and the doors slam shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve seen her ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perenese stoops to lift the box of photographs. His shirt rides up to reveal his pe’a.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sina raises her head. Jake looks at her, his eyes filled hope.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I know who the tattoo belongs to. INT/EXT. JAKE’S CAR/PERENESE HOUSE — NIGHT 118 Jake stops the car. Sina looks up at Jake, flecks of blac her lips.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: (weakly) I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Lock the doors. Jake climbs out of the car. Sina locks the doors behind h A rough neighbourhood by day, it’s scarier by night. Musi booms from a house further up the street. Dogs bark. A fe doors up, NEIGHBOURS sit on the front lawn. Jake walks up to the edge of Perenese’s property and peer around the neighbours’ fence. The house is dark. He scurr up the side of the house. Around the back, Jake tries the back door. It opens. INT. PERENESE HOUSE — NIGHT - CONTINUOUS 119 Jake creeps inside, through the kitchen and into the hall Dim light filters in from the street. Jake pushes open the bedroom door. The photographs of the four young women on the shelf above the bed smile at him the darkness. Jake scans the room, then turns to the mirror. A white cl hangs over it. Jake pulls it away ... to reveal his own reflection. He stares into the dark glass.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Where are you? Jake heads down the hallway, deeper into the house. He pu open a door — a bathroom. The next door is locked. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake stands back, considering ... then, POW! He kicks the door. The wood cracks and the door bangs open. The air ar Jake seems to rush into the room as if into a vacuum. INT. PERENESE HOUSE / BEDROOM — NIGHT 120 Jake crosses to the window and yanks opens the curtains. Street light washes in, illuminating — A boy's room, with a teenage lifetime’s accumulation — a rugby ball, toys, books and cassettes — all neatly arrang on the shelves and dresser, awaiting their owner’s return Photos adorn the walls. A school portrait, a league team, smiling teenager holding up a fish in one, in another wea a suit with a teenage girl on his arm. And a final photo. Jake lifts it from the wall. The Peren family in front of the newly built church — Perenese, his wife, four daughters and his SON, standing at the edge of frame. It’s the same photo Sina found torn in the box of photos, but this one is complete. The young man in the photos is THE TATTOOIST. THUD! From elsewhere in the house. Jake freezes. INT. JAKE’S CAR - NIGHT 121 BANG! The car rocks. Sina jumps. A wind seems to swirl ar her. She looks around nervously. A shape moves in the reflective glass of the windows. INT. PERENESE HOUSE / BEDROOM — NIGHT 122 Voices, the sound of the front door closing. Frantically, Jake looks around for a weapon. INT. PERENESE HOUSE — NIGHT 123 Mr Perenese steps out of the light of the living room int the dark hallway. He calls over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) I don’t want to eat. I’m not hungry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The old man stops in his tracks. Jake stands in the open doorway of the boy’s room, a Samoan cricket bat in one ha the photo still held in the other. Perenese stares Jake down with the eyes of a man who has faced the worst life can deal him.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What did you do to him?

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Your son.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: We don’t speak of him... he brought shame on this house. Mrs Perenese appears in the living room doorway. At the s of Jake, she GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Call the police.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What did he do? Speak up to you in public? Skip church? What? Perenese seems taken aback by Jake’s fury.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: He was a pe’a-mutu. He did not finish his pe’a. You happy now?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And you killed him, you son of a bitch. You were so afraid of what people would think —

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: No! Tears well in Perenese’s eyes, his shoulders bowed with t shame.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If you really cared about him, you'd’ve let him choose whether or not he got a pe’a. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: More than anything, he wanted to be aman! I say, he is too young. But he ask me ... he beg me to get the pe’a.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If he wanted it so bad, then why the hell didn’t he finish? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Before he get the pe’a, I pass on to him the ulalei given to me my father, to give him the strength it gave to my family. He take it from me. I never see it, or him, again.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I've seen him.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Lomi? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I was hoping you could tell me.

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: Please ... I don’t understand. His confusion is genuine. Jake looks away, thinking hard. INT. JAKE’ BANG! The

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: How did you find out he was gone?

dialogues.speaker: PERENESE
dialogues.text: He said he go to the tufuga, for the pe’a. But the tufuga never saw him on that day.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who was doing his pe’a?

dialogues.speaker: S CAR
dialogues.text: car jolts. Sina looks around wildly. Something moves in the wing mirror! She spins again — a dark shape shifts past the rearview mirror. It’s inside the car. CLICK — the car doors unlock in unison! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sina SCREAMS and lunges for the driver's door. She slams locks back down. THUMP! Banging on the glass outside. Sin GASPS — Jake is at the window.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It’s me! Shaking, Sina unlocks the car and Jake gets in. JAKE (CONT’D) His name was Lomi Perenese. And I know who killed him. Jake starts the car. INT. MR VA'A’S HOUSE - NIGHT 125 A vintage stylus rides a wave of warped vinyl as an old record spins. The music is the eerie Samoan song from the dream of the Tattooist, punctuated by the muffled crackle needle on scratched 45. Mr Va'a’s church jacket hangs over the back of his chair. Beyond, Mr Va’a carries a white lace cloth and drapes it the mirror in his living room. BANGING on the front door. His eyes narrow warily. Va'a opens the door ... and relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) Alipati, it’s late. Alipati fingers something in his hand. Va’a looks down: The bone and wood tattooing tool is in his hands. Va'a looks back up, wary once again.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) When you handed down your tools, what else did you pass to me?

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) Come in.  126 127 128 129 92. EXT. MR VA’A’S HOUSE - NIGHT 126 Jake's car pulls up outside Va’a’s house. Jake opens the for Sina and helps her up the side of the house. She moan pain, stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: You can’t ... accuse my uncle of murder ... you need proof.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We'll find it. We just gotta know where to look.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: He used to ... work in his shed. Locked ever since. The faintest TAP-TAP-TAP ... a ghostly memory.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Right in front of my eyes. Light spills out of the living room window onto the pathw ahead. The curtains are open. Jake risks a peep over the windowsill and gapes in surprise. INT. LIVING ROOM — NIGHT 127 Inside, Alipati paces nervously as he speaks to Va’a in e tones. He indicates the tattooing tool that sits on the dining table. Va’a glares at him, eyes blazing. EXT. MR VA’A’S HOUSE - NIGHT 128 Sina retches. Jake cringes and pulls her against him to muffle the sound as droplets of ink patter onto his chest A shadow falls across the pathway ahead. Above them, Mr V looms at the window. He stands sentinel for what seems li an eternity. Below, Jake doesn’t dare to breathe. INT. LIVING ROOM — NIGHT 129 Mr Va‘a stares out of the window. His own reflection on t glass comes into focus. He yanks the curtains closed.  130 131 132 93. EXT. GARDEN — NIGHT 130 Jake breathes a sigh of relief. Keeping low to the ground and Sina stumble towards the shed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Va’a turns from the window to where Alipati paces.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: (in Samoan) It’s always bad luck for them to get the pe’a alone! Alipati turns his back, head down as he gathers his thoug Immediately Va’a moves — lightning quick for a man of his size. He lifts a small table from beside his easy chair a smashes Alipati on the head. Alipati crumples. The song ends as the needle runs into the groove at the e of the 45 ... lifts ... and returns to the beginning. The song starts again. INT. SHED — NIGHT 132 The door scrapes open, sweeping a shaft of moonlight acro old flax mats and dirt floor, a rake and shovel. A dirty mirror leans against one wall. Jake lies Sina against the wall and kneels beside her. Sh fading fast. The tattoo is spreading up her neck now towa her face. He stands, looks around. On the wall, a familiar tapa clo faded with age but recognisable. Jake kneels, examines th flax mats, stained in patches.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I’ve dreamed this place. He pulls up the flax mats. The dirt beneath is packed har but uneven. He grabs the shovel. CLANG! Jake brings the shovel down on the hard earth, dislodging a chunk of it. CLANG-CLANG! He hacks again, churning up the ground to reveal — A dull, pale section of skull. Teeth protrude from its jawbone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Why? Jake crouches and puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It’s finished now — that’s all that matters. Lomi’s got nothing to be ashamed of. Sina nestles her head against him and closes her eyes. Jake looks up, to the dirty mirror against the wall. A glimpse of a dark shape standing over them — CLANG! Sina’s eyes flick open in shock. A massive spasm wracks her body. More lines of pe’a appear, snaking up he neck. Alarmed, Jake turns back to Lomi’s remains.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We know you didn’t run! What more do you want? He stares in anguish at the bones ... and sees something in the dirt. He scrabbles frantically with his hands, unearthing a necklace of long whale teeth, a traditional Samoan ulalei. The one from the image in Mr Perenese’s ho

dialogues.speaker: JAKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not about his shame ... The shame is on his family. The BANG of a door from outside. Jake spins, terrified. H looks out of the shed to see —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head down, Mr Va’a drags Alipati across the garden by his hair.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You're gonna need a bigger shed. Va'a drops Alipati and glares at Jake. Before Jake can ac Va'a steps to the edge of the shed and lifts the machete where it leans. With surprising agility, Mr Va’a lunges. The machete whoo through the air, glances off the iron wall as Jake sidest He tackles Va’a, shoving him out into the garden.  134 135 136 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tattooist emerges from the shadows at the end of the shed, his eyes fixed on Sina. EXT. GARDEN — NIGHT 135 Mr Va'a finds his feet, swings the machete sideways, backhanded, cracking Jake over the head. Jake reels and f on the grass. Va'a stands over him, swings the machete. Jake reaches fo piece of firewood, swings it up like a shield ... the mac whistles down — CHOCK! The blade sticks in the wood. Va’a rips the wood from Jake’s hands and shakes it from the bl He swings again. Jake rolls — THUNK! The blade sinks deep into the ground. Mr Va’a leans down to grasp the machete both hands. Jake scrambles away and races towards the house. INT. KITCHEN / LIVING ROOM — NIGHT 136 Jake slams the kitchen door shut. He locks it - SMASH! Th machete smashes through the glass. Mr Va’a reaches inside clawing for the lock. Jake scrambles into the living room, looking for ... The phone! He snatches up the receiver, reaches for the buttons as — SMASH! The machete cleaves the plastic in tw Jake jumps clear, picks up one of the dining chairs — SMA A blow from the machete shatters it, leaving Jake with a piece of wood.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Didn’t anyone ever tell you not to fuck with an islander with a machete? Mr Va'a swings — THUNK! The blade lodges in the dining ta Jake grabs Mr Va’a in a rugby tackle, slamming him agains the wall. VVVVVVIP! The needle scrapes off the 45 as the record pla crashes to the floor.  137 138 139 140 141 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alipati stirs. He picks himself up, groaning. Blood runs the side of his face. He shakes his head and gets unstead to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sina looks up as the spirit stands over her. His eyes bla with malice. Weakly, she crawls towards the shed door. Th Tattooist raises his hammer — TAP-TAP-CLANG! Sina cries o in agony. A shadow fills the doorway — Alipati. His eyes move from to the excavated grave.

dialogues.speaker: ALIPATI
dialogues.text: Sina? Sina holds something out to Alipati in a shaking hand.

dialogues.speaker: SINA
dialogues.text: Perenese ... take this to Mr Perenese. INT. KITCHEN / LIVING ROOM — NIGHT 139 Jake slams Mr Va’a against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You're a murderer!

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief FLASH of the dream images ... flesh festers and w +. Lomi’s fist clenches in pain. MR VA‘A (V.O.) His pe’a was infected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake glares at Va’‘a. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: He could have been saved ... there are doctors —

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
dialogues.text: Like you, they would not have understood. Va'a shoves Jake back across the room. He advances, wrenc the machete from the table.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: So you killed him and said he ran away — you brought shame on the Pereneses instead of on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lomi gasps in agony on the flax mats. The dark shadow of Va'a stands over him, the machete raised. The blade falls

dialogues.speaker: CHOCK
dialogues.text: INT. LIVING ROOM — NIGHT 143 Jake presses up against the wall as Va'’a approaches, menacing.

dialogues.speaker: MR VA'A
